   Assessment and Plan
   This 48 year old woman with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolongued
   hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement
   along with gram negative bacteremia and candidemia returned from her
   rehab facility with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of
   recently diagnosed C difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the
   MICU with altered mental status.
   .
   * Candidemia
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood culture
   correlates with being off micafungin on the floor, repeat cultures are
   negative. Her PICC is now out, though her original HD catheter is still
   in place. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole. If seeded bone/heart etc. or abscess formation longer
   course would have been required.
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities
   - Remove HD catheter, send tip for culture
   - Follow up pending cultures and repeat glucan
   - Will need eye exam
   - CT torso for look again for abscess
   - ID recs appreciated
   * Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. In setting of anticoagulation, consider also head
   bleed though would not expect her mental status to improve quickly
   without intervention. No obvious focal deficits, though neuro exam
   limited.
   - Hold all sedating meds
   - Will defer on narcan for now as mental status improved
   - CT head, holding heparin pending this study
   - Minimize sedation and follow neurologic exam closely
   - Consider EEG
   .
   * Leukocytosis
   Persistly elevated WBC in setting of recent rehab diagnosis of C diff,
   abdominal wound, multiple venous thromboses, lines and recent TPN. She
   continues to have fevers despite very broad spectrum treatment
   including meropenem, vancomycin PO and IV, micafungin. Her blood
   cultures have not grown any organisms and her ascites did not show
   evidence of infection on presentation. However her glucan was very high
   at presentation however, though we do not have a level from her prior
   admission. C diff assay here, in setting of treatment, was negative.
   Would consider: occult intrabdominal abscess, though not commented on
   admission CT abdomen; septic thrombophlebitis; empyema (R effusion
   loculated on CXR); line infection; endocarditis due to fastidious
   organism; severe C difficile infection. An untreated fungal infection
   whether due to anatomic barrier eg abscess or resistant mold needs to
   be considered with her high glucan.
   Of noninfectious causes, which I think are much less likely explanatory
   for her fevers and leukocytosis consider drug fever, vasculitis (eg PAN
   given hepB), clots.
   - Will continue current IV meropenem, IV vancomycin, PO vancomycin, IV
   metronidazole for now. Vanc level therapeutic today. If hemodynamically
   unstable consider amphotericin. If C diff diagnosis confirmed would
   treat with PO vanco at least 10d beyond end of systemic abx
   - Favor repeating CT abdomen with IV and PO contrast to assess for
   abscess
   - Would consider tapping R pleural effusion. Reasonable to consider
   repeat paracentesis again.
   - Would pull her R picc which has been in place for some time. Send tip
   for culture.
   - Repeating beta glucan today to assess response to micafungin
   - Follow up pending micro and culture if febrile
   - Confirm OSH C diff diagnosis
   .
   * Hypoxia
   Suspect this is due to volume overload primarily. Given her other clots
   would consider PE, though I think this is less likely as she has been
   on systemic anticoagulation. Could have aspirated in setting of altered
   mental status
   - Would favor additional volume removal at HD
   - Consider repeating TTE with bubble study
   - Repeat ABG
   - Likely able to extubate today as she is more awake
   .
   * Abdominal wound
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   * Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin pending head CT
   - Holding warfarin for now given anticipated procedures
   .
   * HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy
   S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   * ESRD on HD
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   * DM
   - Continue insulin
   .
   * HTN
   BP near her recent baseline. Note that thigh pressures likely
   underestimate her BP.
   - Hold on further IVF at this time
   - Holding lisinopril
   .
   * Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>25
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and a history of prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) with abdominal abscess, gram-negative bacteremia, and candidemia. She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with altered mental status and is currently intubated for airway protection. The patient has multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), autoimmune cholangiopathy, and anemia.

Medical Complications:
1. Candidemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast, indicating candidemia. It is likely line-related, considering her total parenteral nutrition (TPN). She had a previous infection with Candida glabrata, which was treated with fluconazole. Micafungin has been continued pending speciation and sensitivities.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's acute onset of altered mental status is concerning for a seizure. Other possible causes include sedating medication effects, anticoagulation-related bleeding, or focal deficits. An EEG and CT head are planned to further evaluate the cause.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient has persistently elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, which could be due to occult intrabdominal abscess, septic thrombophlebitis, empyema

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 48-year-old woman with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and a recent prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) with abdominal abscess debridement.
- She was also diagnosed with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia.
- The patient presented with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis, indicating an infection.
- She was transferred back to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) with altered mental status.
- The patient's current conditions include altered mental status, leukocytosis, hypoxia, abdominal wound, portal venous and right internal jugular (RIJ) clots, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, ESRD on HD, diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), and anemia.
- She has been intubated for airway protection and is receiving mechanical ventilation.
- The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.2Â°C, blood pressure ranging from 127/53 to 156/67 mmHg, heart rate of 79 bpm, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal coagulation parameters.
- Imaging studies reveal pleural effusion and abdominal fluid collection.
-

   Assessment and Plan
   This 48 year old woman with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolongued
   hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement
   along with gram negative bacteremia and candidemia returned from her
   rehab facility with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of
   recently diagnosed C difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the
   MICU with altered mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   * Candidemia
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood culture
   correlates with being off micafungin on the floor, repeat cultures are
   negative. Her PICC is now out, though her original HD catheter is still
   in place. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate.
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities
   - Remove HD catheter, send tip for culture
   - Follow up pending cultures and repeat glucan
   - Will need eye exam
   - CT torso for look again for abscess
   - Repeat TTE, if negative and repeat + culture after HD lines out will
   need TEE
   - ID recs appreciated
   * Leukocytosis and fever
   At this point, leading dx is disseminated fungal infection, though she
   came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please see admit
   note for detailed ddx discussion. [**Female First Name (un) **] yesterday showed no evidence of
   empyema.
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco for now pending HD line
   removal/culture and CT torso. If nothing comes back, plan to keep on
   for 48hrs after code
   - TEE to r/o vegetations
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C diff diagnosis
   .
   * Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT.
   - Reassess with lightening of sedation
   - Check EEG
   - Consider neuro c/s
   * Hypoxia
   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect this is fluid
   related or related to altered mental status
   Favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   * Hypotension
   Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely, cardiogenic. Her propofol may be
   contributory. She appears intravascularly volume overloaded.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   - Add on AM cortisol, and if still hypotensive, consider stress dose
   steroids
   .
   * Abdominal wound
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   * Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Stop heparin in anticipation of pulling HD line
   - Holding warfarin for now given anticipated procedures
   .
   * HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy
   S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   * ESRD on HD
   Removing HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent
   need for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   * DM
   - Continue insulin
   .
   * Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old woman with a complex medical history including ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement, along with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. She was transferred back to the MICU with altered mental status and found to have candidemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the information provided include:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has been diagnosed with candidemia, which is a systemic fungal infection. If left untreated or inadequately treated, it can lead to disseminated fungal infection involving other organs such as the heart, bones, or lungs.

2. Line-related infection: The patient's candidemia is likely line-related, especially considering her recent use of TPN. If the source of infection is not appropriately managed, it can result in further complications such as sepsis or deep-seated abscesses.

3. Hepatitis B: The patient has a history of HBV. If her immune system becomes compromised due to prolonged illness or treatments, there is a risk of liver damage or reinfection.

4. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient has been treated with prednisone, which is an immunosuppressive medication. This treatment may increase the risk of autoimmune cholangiopathy, a condition characterized by inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts.

5. Renal complications: As the patient has ESRD on HD

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B, and a history of prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement due to an abdominal abscess. She also has gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. The patient presented to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with altered mental status and worsening leukocytosis, in the setting of recently diagnosed Clostridium difficile colitis.

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications include:

1. Candidemia: The patient has positive blood cultures for yeast, indicating candidemia. This is likely line-related, especially since she was receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient had a previous line infection caused by Candida glabrata, which was treated with fluconazole for 23 days. If there is seeding of the bone, heart, venous clots, or abscess formation, a longer course of antifungal treatment may be necessary.

2. Leukocytosis and fever: The patient has leukocytosis and fever, which are common signs of infection. The leading diagnosis is disseminated fungal infection, although she had a reported C. difficile infection at the rehabilitation facility. Further investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

3. Altered mental status: The patient experienced an acute onset of altered mental status, which improved rapidly after intubation for airway protection

   Assessment and Plan
   This 48 year old woman with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolongued
   hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement
   along with gram negative bacteremia and candidemia returned from her
   rehab facility with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of
   recently diagnosed C difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the
   MICU with altered mental status.
   .
   * Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. In setting of anticoagulation, consider also head
   bleed though would not expect her mental status to improve quickly
   without intervention. No obvious focal deficits, though neuro exam
   limited.
   - Hold all sedating meds
   - Will defer on narcan for now as mental status improved
   - CT head, holding heparin pending this study
   - Minimize sedation and follow neurologic exam closely
   - Consider EEG
   .
   * Leukocytosis
   Persistly elevated WBC in setting of recent rehab diagnosis of C diff,
   abdominal wound, multiple venous thromboses, lines and recent TPN. She
   continues to have fevers despite very broad spectrum treatment
   including meropenem, vancomycin PO and IV, micafungin. Her blood
   cultures have not grown any organisms and her ascites did not show
   evidence of infection on presentation. However her glucan was very high
   at presentation however, though we do not have a level from her prior
   admission. C diff assay here, in setting of treatment, was negative.
   Would consider: occult intrabdominal abscess, though not commented on
   admission CT abdomen; septic thrombophlebitis; empyema (R effusion
   loculated on CXR); line infection; endocarditis due to fastidious
   organism; severe C difficile infection. An untreated fungal infection
   whether due to anatomic barrier eg abscess or resistant mold needs to
   be considered with her high glucan.
   Of noninfectious causes, which I think are much less likely explanatory
   for her fevers and leukocytosis consider drug fever, vasculitis (eg PAN
   given hepB), clots.
   - Will continue current IV meropenem, IV vancomycin, PO vancomycin, IV
   metronidazole for now. Vanc level therapeutic today. If hemodynamically
   unstable consider amphotericin. If C diff diagnosis confirmed would
   treat with PO vanco at least 10d beyond end of systemic abx
   - Favor repeating CT abdomen with IV and PO contrast to assess for
   abscess
   - Would consider tapping R pleural effusion. Reasonable to consider
   repeat paracentesis again.
   - Would pull her R picc which has been in place for some time. Send tip
   for culture.
   - Repeating beta glucan today to assess response to micafungin
   - Follow up pending micro and culture if febrile
   - Confirm OSH C diff diagnosis
   .
   * Hypoxia
   Suspect this is due to volume overload primarily. Given her other clots
   would consider PE, though I think this is less likely as she has been
   on systemic anticoagulation. Could have aspirated in setting of altered
   mental status
   - Would favor additional volume removal at HD
   - Consider repeating TTE with bubble study
   - Repeat ABG
   - Likely able to extubate today as she is more awake
   .
   * Abdominal wound
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   * Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin pending head CT
   - Holding warfarin for now given anticipated procedures
   .
   * HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy
   S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   * ESRD on HD
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   * DM
   - Continue insulin
   .
   * HTN
   BP near her recent baseline. Note that thigh pressures likely
   underestimate her BP.
   - Hold on further IVF at this time
   - Holding lisinopril
   .
   * Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>25

She continues to have fevers, and blood cultures have not grown any organisms. Her ascites did not show evidence of infection on presentation, but her glucan level was very high.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and end-stage liver disease (ESLD), who recently had an abdominal wound infection with Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection. The patient is currently in the ICU with altered mental status and is intubated on mechanical ventilation. She has been receiving multiple antibiotics and antifungal medications.

24-hour events include being trialed on pressure support ventilation (PSV) but became tachypneic. The patient has no known drug allergies and has received various doses of antibiotics since April 14th. She is currently on propofol infusion and heparin sodium infusion.

Physical examination reveals that the patient is thin, with diminished right radial pulse, absent right distal pulse, and decreased breath sounds in the chest. She also has cool skin, muscle wasting, and edema in both lower extremities.

Lab results show leukocytosis with a high white blood cell count, elevated creatinine levels, and elevated lactate levels. Other lab values indicate abnormalities in electrolytes, liver enzymes, and kidney function.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Leukocytosis/fever with positive Candida auris blood culture - discontinuation of PICC line, removal of central venous catheter, continuation of vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole, consideration of transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to rule out endocarditis.
2. Clostridium difficile infection - continuation of oral vancomycin and metronidazole.
3. Altered mental status - unclear etiology, possible sepsis, ruling out seizure activity with an electroencephalogram (EEG), continuous monitoring of neuro status.
4. Respiratory failure - transition to pressure support ventilation (PSV) and weaning off mechanical ventilation.
5. Hypotension - propofol infusion and volume shifts in setting of large volume paracentesis, continuous intravenous fluid resuscitation, consideration of levophed, and albumin administration if refractory.
6. Heparin for portal vein thrombosis - will hold for 6 hours prior to discontinuing the hemodialysis line.
7. Autoimmune cholangiopathy - completed steroid taper.
8. DM2 - RISS.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and positive blood culture suggest an ongoing infection, which can lead to sepsis. Immediate intervention is required to control the infection and prevent further deterioration.
2. Endocarditis: Given the positive Candida auris blood culture, there is a concern for endocarditis. A TEE should be performed to rule out this condition.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and weaning off mechanical ventilation should be done cautiously to avoid further complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is concerning, especially in the setting of recent paracentesis. Close monitoring and aggressive fluid resuscitation are necessary to maintain adequate blood pressure.
5. Portal vein thrombosis: The patient's history of ESLD and the use of heparin suggest a concern for portal

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and end-stage liver disease (ELSD). She has a recent history of abdominal wound infection with Clostridium difficile (C. diff) and is currently admitted to the ICU with altered mental status. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and has multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type 2, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and possible hepatocellular carcinoma.

24-hour events:
- Trialed on pressure support ventilation (PSV) but became tachypneic.
- No known drug allergies.

   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .

   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new RIJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate.  L thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma cx NGTD. . Still
   fevers overnight to 101F range. Weaned pressors overnight but now back
   on due to overnight SBPs dropping to 70s.  WBC slightly down from 26 to
   22 range.
   Ascites drainage negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.
   .

   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring
   pressors. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has 2 IJs in
   place still.
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco
   - HD line removal/culture and CT torso. If nothing comes back, plan to

   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C diff diagnosis
   .
   * Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA

   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT.

   Favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or

   - surgery following, recs appreciated

   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of recent sepsis, C.diff infection, and multiple abdominal infections. She presents with altered mental status and is currently intubated for airway protection. The patient has been diagnosed with candidemia and likely line-related in the setting of total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Blood cultures are positive for yeast, indicating a fungal infection. The patient's condition is complicated by several medical issues, including end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis (ESRD), hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and portal venous and right internal jugular vein clots.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has candidemia and is at risk for further spread of the infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing fevers, leukocytosis, hypotension, and need for vasopressors suggest ongoing sepsis.
3. Hepatitis B: The patient has hepatitis B, which can lead to liver complications and require specific treatment.
4. Autoimmune cholangiopathy: The patient's autoimmune condition affecting the bile ducts may require ongoing management and monitoring.
5. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has diabetes, which needs to be controlled through insulin therapy.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia requires monitoring and possible transfusion support.
7. Portal venous and right internal jugular vein clots:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 48-year-old woman with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), and recent prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) due to an abdominal abscess. She was also diagnosed with gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. The patient presented to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with altered mental status and candidemia. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Candidemia: The patient has candidemia, which is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. This infection is likely line-related, especially since she was receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient's previous line infection with C. glabrata was treated with fluconazole for 23 days. If the candidemia has spread to other organs such as the bone, heart, or venous clots, a longer treatment duration may be necessary. 

2. Leukocytosis and Fever: The patient's leukocytosis and fever could be attributed to the disseminated fungal infection. However, she also had a reported case of Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection at her rehabilitation facility. Further investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis of C. diff.

3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's acute onset of altered mental status and rapid improvement raises concerns for a seizure. It is important to reassess her condition with

   rehab facility with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 48-year-old woman with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B (HBV), recent prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) due to an abdominal abscess, gram-negative bacteremia, and candidemia. She was transferred back to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with altered mental status and found to have candidemia. The patient has leukocytosis and fever, altered mental status, hypoxia, hypotension, an abdominal wound, portal venous and right internal jugular (RIJ) clots, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, ESRD on HD, diabetes mellitus (DM), and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has candidemia and a history of previous C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole for 23 days. There is a concern for the possibility of seeding in organs such as the bone, heart, or venous clots.

2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, especially considering her positive blood cultures indicating candidemia and gram-negative bacteremia.

3. Hypoxia: The patient has hypoxia, which may be related to fluid overload or altered mental status. It is important to continue weaning off sedation and ensuring proper oxygen

   4.17 HD cath tip cx pending
   4.16 PICC  tip cx pending
   4.15 pleural fluid cx pending
   4.17 ascites cx pending
   4.16 c diff negative
   CXR ET tube ~5cm, clear lung fields
   4.16 CT torso prelim
   1. moderate to large ascites in abdomen and pelvis.
   2. diffuse bowel wall thickening of small and large bowel. could be due
   to 3rd
   spacing, hypoalbumen.; given history of c difficile, large bowel wall
   thickening also likely represents colitis.
   3. periportal edema with heterogeneous enhancement of liver, unchanged.
   4. cholelithiasis.
   5. splenic infarcts.
   6. continued hypoenhancement of kidneys, unchanged, again concerning
   for
   cortical necrosis.
   7. diffuse anasarca, worsened.
   8. small left fluid collection, concerning for abscess, again seen in
   medial
   left thigh, only very superior aspect imaged.
   Assessment and Plan
   This 48 year old woman with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolongued
   hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement
   along with gram negative bacteremia and candidemia returned from her
   rehab facility with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of
   recently diagnosed C difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the
   MICU with altered mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   * Candidemia
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood culture
   correlates with being off micafungin on the floor, repeat cultures are
   negative. Her PICC is now out, though her original HD catheter is still
   in place. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate.  L thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma cx NGTD
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities
   - Needs to have IJ from 4.15 removed
   - Will need eye exam
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week
   - f/u final CT torso read
   - f/u repeat glucan
   - daily blood cultures, f/u pending micro
   - ID recs appreciated
   * Leukocytosis and fever
   At this point, leading dx is disseminated fungal infection, though she
   came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please see admit
   note for detailed ddx discussion. [**Female First Name (un) **] yesterday showed no evidence of
   empyema.
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco for now pending HD line
   removal/culture and CT torso. If nothing comes back, plan to keep on
   for 48hrs after code
   - [**Female First Name (un) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C diff diagnosis
   .
   * Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT.
   - Reassess with lightening of sedation
   - Check EEG
   - Consider neuro c/s
   * Hypoxia
   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect this is fluid
   related or related to altered mental status
   Favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   * Hypotension
   Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely, cardiogenic. Her propofol may be
   contributory. She appears intravascularly volume overloaded.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   - Add on AM cortisol, and if still hypotensive, consider stress dose
   steroids
   .
   * Abdominal wound
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   * Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   * HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy
   S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   * ESRD on HD
   Removing HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent
   need for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   * DM
   - Continue insulin
   .
   * Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, and a history of prolonged hospitalization for a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement due to an abdominal abscess. She presented to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in the setting of recently diagnosed Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis. The patient was found to have candidemia, likely line-related in the setting of total parenteral nutrition (TPN). She also has a positive blood culture for yeast and a history of prior Candida glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole for 23 days.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has candidemia, which may progress to disseminated fungal infection if not appropriately managed.
2. Line-related infection: The patient has a history of previous line-related infections, including Candida glabrata infection.
3. C. diff infection: The patient has recently been diagnosed with C. diff colitis, which can lead to complications such as pseudomembranous colitis, toxic megacolon, or fulminant colitis.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis secondary to the disseminated fungal infection or other underlying conditions.
5. Altered mental status

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hepatitis B cirrhosis. He has been in the ICU for a prolonged period after experiencing complications from an abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. The patient is currently dealing with fungemia as well. 

The patient's current assessment includes hypotension, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), chronic renal failure, and sepsis. The likely source of sepsis is fungemia. The patient's lines have been changed, but cultures from previous days are still positive. There is concern that the fungus may be colonizing intravascular clots.

The plan of care includes continuing micafungin until the sensitivity of the fungus is known. The inferior vena cava (IVC) line will be changed to a new site, and the arterial line will be repositioned. Antibacterials may be reduced if cultures from yesterday are negative at 48 hours. A nephrology consult is scheduled for next week, and daily surveillance cultures will be performed.

In terms of respiratory management, the patient is oxygenating well but is currently overventilating on assist-control (A/C) mode. A pressure support ventilation (PSV) trial will be conducted today since ascites and effusion have improved with taps.

Regarding Clostridium difficile (C. diff), vancomycin and metronidazole will be continued, and it

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hepatitis B cirrhosis. He has been in the ICU for a prolonged period after experiencing complications from an abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. The patient now has fungemia and is critically ill. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is likely suffering from sepsis due to fungemia. Lines have been changed, but previous cultures were positive, indicating the possibility of colonization by fungus in intravascular clots. 
   - Continue micafungin until the sensitivity of the fungus is known.
   - Change the inferior vena cava (IVC) line to a new site and re-site the arterial line.
   - If cultures from yesterday are negative at 48 hours, antibacterials may be scaled back.
   - Perform a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) next week.
   - Conduct daily surveillance cultures.
   - Schedule an ophthalmic consultation.
   - Maintain a small amount of pressors. Keep central venous pressure (CVP) reasonable. Continue pressors and wean as able. Avoid excessive fluid administration due to ESRD and preference for a line holiday for as long as possible.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is oxygenating well but is overventilated on assist-control (A/C) mode. Some tachypnea was observed earlier in the week

   CT torso:
   1. No CT evidence of disseminated fungal infection. Large amount of
   ascites
   within the abdomen and pelvis. Diffuse bowel wall thickening which may
   be
   related to third spacing. However, given history of C. difficile
   infection,
   bowel wall thickening of the colon could also represent colitis.
   2. Continued hypoenhancement of the kidneys bilaterally, unchanged from
   [**4-5**], [**2168**], again concerning for cortical necrosis.
   3. Peripheral nonenhancement of the spleen, unchanged, consistent with
   splenic infarction.
   4. Central venous line ends within the upper inferior vena cava,
   unchanged.
   5. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis.
   6. Diffuse anasarca, worsening.
   Assessment and Plan :
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia returned from her rehab facility with
   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis transferred back to the MICU with altered mental
   status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Lines re-changed yesterday [**4-16**]. Patient
   had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole x23d. If
   seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess formation 3 week course would
   have likely been inadequate. Left thigh fluid collection previously
   drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from thigh NGTD.  She had no more
   fevers overnight but  is still very dependent on pressors. WBC still
   elevated at 23 ( has been ranging  22-26) .  So far, ascites drainage
   negative for SBP and no fungus growing to date.  She has clean eye exam
   with ophthalmology yesterday.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs
   - Continue micafungin & additional Ambisome
   - daily blood cultures for now
   - holding all TPN for now
   - new A-line and right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all
   old lines removed
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan & dimorphic fungi blood cultures
   -  f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBCs still in 22-23 range but fevers
   have tapered. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  - trending
   fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - ID following, discuss regarding taking off antibacterials
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant pseudomonas)
   but talk to ID regarding whether needs these, IV vanco and PO vanco
   given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Mental
   status improved today.
   - Trial SBT again today for 30-60min to see whether can trial
   extubation today
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration.
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Still intubated for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low dose Levophed but unable
   to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with recent sepsis, C. difficile infection, and multiple abdominal infections. She presents with altered mental status and now has candidemia with pressor-dependent blood pressure. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, diabetes mellitus, and anemia. She is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 37.1Â°C, heart rate of 68 bpm, blood pressure of 112/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is receiving multiple intravenous medications including norepinephrine, heparin, propofol, and various antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has leukocytosis and fever, which could be indicative of a disseminated fungal infection. The recent diagnosis of C. difficile infection and candidemia supports this concern.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic physiology requiring pressors intermittently suggests ongoing sepsis.
3. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for airway protection but is now oxygenating better. However, there is still tachypnea on pressure support ventilation (PSV), suggesting possible fluid-related or altered mental status-related hypoxia

She presents with altered mental status and now has candidemia with blood pressure-dependent on pressors. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has leukocytosis and fever, which suggests a possible disseminated fungal infection. She also has candidemia and a history of C. glabrata line infection treated with fluconazole.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and septic physiology require pressors intermittently, indicating ongoing sepsis.
3. Hypoxia: The patient is intubated mainly for airway protection, and oxygenation is better today but tachypneic on PSV. This may be related to fluid overload or altered mental status.
4. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may be due to sepsis, fluid overload, or cardiogenic causes. Weaning of pressors and appropriate fluid management are necessary.
5. Abdominal wound infection: The patient has an abdominal wound that requires ongoing wound care and potential surgical intervention.
6. Portal venous and right internal jugular (RIJ) clots: The patient has a history of portal venous and RIJ

   lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in setting of recently diagnosed
   C.difficile colitis. She is transferred back to the MICU with altered
   mental status and found to have candidemia.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   Likely line related in the setting of TPN. Positive blood cultures ( on
   [**5-15**] and [**4-14**])  correlate with being off micafungin on the floor,
   repeat cultures are negative. Her PICC  & HD now pulled out and new IJ
   placed [**4-14**]. Patient had prior C. glabrata line infection treated with
   fluconazole x23d. If seeded bone/heart/venous clots or abscess
   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD. . Still fevers overnight to 101F range. Weaned pressors
   overnight but now back  on due to overnight SBPs dropping to 70s.  WBC
   slightly down from 26 to 22 range. Ascites drainage negative for SBP
   and no fungus growing to date.
   .
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities.
   - daily cultures for now
   - stop TPN for now
   - holding off on Ambisome for now
   - may need to have left IJ removed  that was placed [**4-14**] given positive
   cultures on that date
   - consider femoral line placement this afternoon vs. new HD line ( will
   d/w renal)
   - will likely need new A-line as well
   - will need eye exam / ophthalmology consult today

   - f/u final CT torso final read

   well
   - f/up ID recs, appreciate input

   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has left
   IJs in place still.
   - trending fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read

   - formal eye exam/ophthalmology consult as above
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C. diff diagnosis
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low

She presents with altered mental status and candidemia with blood pressure-dependent pressors. The patient has undergone several interventions including changing wound vac, removing HD line, placing new right femoral CVL and R A-line, and restarting heparin drip. She is currently intubated for airway protection and on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's leukocytosis and persistent fever suggest a disseminated fungal infection, which is consistent with her recent diagnosis of C.difficile colitis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and requirement for pressors indicate ongoing sepsis. Her altered mental status and tachypnea may be related to fluid overload or infection.
3. Hypoxia: Intubation was performed primarily for airway protection rather than overt respiratory failure. However, the patient's oxygenation has improved, but she remains tachypneic on pressure support ventilation (PSV).

   formation 3 week course would have likely been inadequate. Left thigh
   fluid collection previously drained c/w hematoma and all cultures from
   thigh NGTD. . Still fevers overnight to 101F range. Weaned pressors
   overnight but now back  on due to overnight SBPs dropping to 70s.  WBC
   slightly down from 26 to 22 range. Ascites drainage negative for SBP
   and no fungus growing to date.
   .
   - Continue micafungin for now pending speciation and sensitivities.
   - daily cultures for now
   - stop TPN for now
   - holding off on Ambisome for now
   - may need to have left IJ removed  that was placed [**4-14**] given positive
   cultures on that date
   - consider femoral line placement this afternoon vs. new HD line ( will
   d/w renal)
   - will likely need new A-line as well
   - will need eye exam / ophthalmology consult today
   - [**Last Name (LF) 1163**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] be done next week once more stable
   - f/u final CT torso final read
   - f/u repeat glucan / galactomannan
   - daily blood cultures, f/u pending micro from ascites & pleural tap as
   well
   - f/up ID recs, appreciate input
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. Thoracentesis yesterday
   showed no evidence of empyema.  WBC slight drop to 22 today, fevers
   continued to 101F overnight. Still septic physiology requiring pressors
   intermittently. HD line has been removed, PICC removed.  Now has left
   IJs in place still.
   - trending fevers, WBC slowly coming down
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - Continuing on cefepime, amikacin (to cover for resistant
   pseudomonas), IV vanco and PO vanco given recent C.diff
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - f/up final  CT torso read
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1163**] to r/o vegetations
   - formal eye exam/ophthalmology consult as above
   - CIS
   - Confirm OSH C. diff diagnosis
   .
   # Altered mental status
   Now s/p intubation for airway protection. The acute onset of this event
   and rapid improvement is worrisome for a seizure. With her prior CVA
   and meropenem treatment with active infection would be concerned for
   seizure. Would also consider sedating med effect eg: dilaudid, though
   she was reportedly feeling well several hours after receiving a low
   dose of PO dilaudid. No evidence of bleed on head CT. EEG with no
   active seizures.
   - wean  sedation as tolerates
   -  treating infections as above
   - Consider neuro c/s
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt resp
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, but tachypneic on PSV, suspect
   this is fluid related or related to altered mental status.  Now had 2L
   taken off abd yesterday and pleural effusions better.
   -favor additional volume removal, may need CVVH. Less likely PE or
   aspiration. On AC ventilation
   - Would pursue additional volume removal as BP tolerates, may need CVVH
   - Continue on AC until done with procedures, then can trial on PS
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] sepsis. Less likely cardiogenic. Her
   propofol may be contributory. She appears intravascularly volume
   overloaded. Normal cortisol levels this morning. CVP 12 now.
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed intermittently
   - Treating infection as above
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed yesterday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin in anticipation of new line
   .
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   .
   # ESRD on HD
   Removed HD line as above, sending for culture. Per renal no urgent need
   for HD today. Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Also d/w renal
   new line options/discussion.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Follow lytes daily
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of sepsis, C.difficile infection, and multiple abdominal infections. She presents with altered mental status and has been diagnosed with candidemia. The patient is on hemodialysis (HD) due to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and has been experiencing hypotension, leukocytosis, and fever. She has an abdominal wound that required debridement and is being managed with wound vac. The patient also has a history of hepatitis B and autoimmune cholangiopathy. She is currently on entecavir, tenofovir, and ursodiol. The patient's recent labs show elevated WBC count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and elevated liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's leukocytosis and fever may indicate a disseminated fungal infection, which needs to be further investigated and treated.
2. Candidemia: The patient has already been diagnosed with candidemia and is being treated with antifungal medication. It is important to monitor the response to treatment and adjust accordingly.
3. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, altered mental status, and fever suggest ongoing sepsis. Prompt and appropriate management is crucial to prevent further complications.
4. C.difficile infection: Although the patient's C.difficile test is currently negative, there is a history of infection, and precautions should be taken

The patient is a 48-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hepatitis B virus (HBV) cirrhosis. He has had a prolonged course after a recent complicated abdominal wound and polymicrobial bacteremia. Currently, he is experiencing sepsis likely due to fungemia. His lines have been changed, and he is now on micafungin and ambisome per Infectious Disease (ID) recommendations. The culture suggests Candida albicans, and the regimen will be tailored accordingly. The patient also requires a small amount of pressors and continues to wean as able.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation on pressure support ventilation (PSV) mode. A spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) was performed this morning, and if successful, the plan is to extubate the patient today. He has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for Clostridium difficile (C. diff), which will likely require a prolonged course. 

The patient's mental status is altered, but it has cleared quickly. A head CT was unremarkable, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) showed diffuse slowing, suggesting a toxic or metabolic cause. The patient is following commands and nodding appropriately today. 

Renal function is currently on hold, and there is no clear indication for renal replacement therapy (RRT) today. However, volume management will eventually become an issue.

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and hepatitis B virus (HBV) cirrhosis. He has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) after a prolonged course of abdominal wound infection and polymicrobial bacteremia. The patient now presents with fungemia, likely caused by Candida albicans. All lines have been changed, and the patient is being treated with micafungin and ambisome per infectious disease (ID) recommendations. The ID will discuss the possibility of scaling back some of the antibacterial regimen, which is currently empirical.

Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is likely suffering from sepsis due to fungemia. There is concern that the fungus may be colonizing intravascular clots.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure and is overventilating on pressure support ventilation (PSV) 12/5. A spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) has been performed, and if it is successful, the patient may be extubated today.
3. Clostridium difficile (C. diff): The patient has C. diff infection, and it is being treated with continued administration of vancomycin and metronidazole. A prolonged course of treatment is anticipated.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, possibly due to toxicity or metabolic imbalances. He is responsive to

 INVASIVE VENTILATION - STOP [**2168-4-17**] 10:15 AM

   Assessment and Plan
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia readmitted with C.difficile colitis and found
   to have new candidemia with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans.
   .
   # Candidemia / Sepsis
   - Patient with positive BCx [**4-11**], [**4-13**], [**4-14**] with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans
   likely in setting of TPN while off micafungin on floor. new A-line and
   right femoral CVL re-sited [**4-16**] for fresh access / all old lines
   removed
   Patient
s abx narrowed yesterday to remain only on micafungin, and
   cdiff coverage (PO vanc/flagyl). WBC continues to trend upwards without
   fever
 other site cultures have been negative (pleural fluid, left
   thigh fluid collection, peritoneal tap). Other site of seeding could be
   her valve with plan for TEE this week.
   .
   - ID following, appreciate recs regarding send out fungal sensitivities
   - Continue micafungin (restarted [**4-14**]) and cdiff tx with PO vanc
   (day#1=[**4-1**]) and flagyl (day #1=[**4-5**])
   - f/u cultures
   - holding all TPN for now
   - plan for TEE tomorrow
 call TEE fellow to confirm today
   .
   # Leukocytosis and fever: Most likely disseminated fungal infection,
   though she came with report of C. diff infection at her rehab. Please
   see admit note for detailed ddx discussion. No more fevers, but WBC
   trending upwards. Other sites to evaluate include abdominal wound and
   heart valves. Still septic physiology requiring low dose pressors.
   - ID following -
   - Fungemia w/u and treatment as above
   - f/up pending culture data, daily cultures
   - TEE to r/o vegetations
   - will hold off on repeat IR drainage of thigh fluid collections
   - continue CIS
   .
   #Hypoxia: Intubated mainly for airway protection vs. overt respiratory
   failure.   Oxygenating better today, now on nasal cannula and doing
   well at 2L .  Initial SOB may have been fluid related or related to
   altered mental status. Less likely PE or aspiration.  Mental status
   improved today.
   - s/p extubation and doing well on NC at 2L , wean as tolerates
   - d/c Fentanyl today to limit sedation  ( Tylenol PRN)
   - favor additional volume removal, will get CVVH today.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Extubated yesterday and maintaining airway
   since. Mental status improved, but patient still lethargic with low
   energy. No evidence of seizures s/p extubation. Would be careful with
   narcotic medications as could have played role in lathergy/transfer
   back to MICU. Also may have element of uremia and hepatic related
   encephalopathy.
   -  continue to hold narcotics for now
   - getting CVVH , will help uremia effects
   -  treating infections as above
   - start lactulose today, follow up liver recs
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] septic etiology. She appears
   intravascularly volume overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low
   dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed
   - monitor closely in setting of upcoming dialysis / CVVH today
   - Treating infection as above
   # ESRD on HD:
   Given pressor requirement, may need CVVH. Plan for CVVH/HD today with
   placement of temp HD catheter today. Heparin on hold this AM in
   preparation
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Plan for temp line placement and CVVH/HD today
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   Nutrition will be issue for the patient. Had abdominal infection s/p
   PEG placement, now with candidemia likely in setting of TPN.
   - Nutrition:  Dophoff placement for now vs re-evaluate ability to take
   POs (as will likely will not be enough intake & very  poor gag reflex
   now)
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia issues
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests
   - Liver recs appreciated
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac in place
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - On heparin gtt
 holding for AM for HD catheter placement but will
   resume after procedure later today
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI until better
   intake w/Dobhoff feeds
   .
   # Anemia
   - Hct stable, continue to follow daily.
   - Maintain active T+S and transfuse for hct>21
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: feeds with Dobhoff once placed
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement, and abdominal abscess requiring debridement. She has been readmitted with C. difficile colitis and new candidemia caused by Candida albicans. The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
- The patient was successfully extubated on [**4-17**] and is now on a nasal cannula with improved oxygenation.
- She has been experiencing pain in her right lower extremity, for which she received two boluses of fentanyl.
- The patient's antibiotic regimen has been narrowed down to remain only on micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
- She will require hemodialysis (HD) today, and a temporary HD line will be placed tomorrow. Heparin gtt needs to be discontinued at 6 am tomorrow, and she will likely need 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) prior to the procedure.
- The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3Â°C (97.4Â°F), heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 110/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.
- Her review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the recent pain

- The patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis.
- She was successfully extubated on [**4-17**] and is now on micafungin and C. difficile coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl.
- The patient requires hemodialysis (HD) today, and a temporary HD line will be placed tomorrow. Heparin gtt needs to be turned off at 6 am tomorrow, and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) will be required prior to the procedure.
- The patient has a history of prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) with abdominal abscess, gram-negative bacteremia, and candidemia.
- She has a new diagnosis of candidemia with Candida albicans.
- The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) continues to trend upwards without fever, indicating a possible disseminated fungal infection.
- Other sites to evaluate include the abdominal wound and heart valves.
- The patient is still septic physiology requiring low-dose pressors.
- She is hypoxic, mainly due to airway protection rather than overt respiratory failure.
- The patient's mental status has improved since extubation but remains lethargic with low energy.
- She is hypotensive and suspect septic etiology, requiring low-dose levophed but unable

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of ESRD on HD, HBV, and recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG placement, who was readmitted with C. difficile colitis and found to have new candidemia with Candida albicans. She is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications including sepsis, candidemia, hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, anemia, and DM.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has been diagnosed with candidemia, which can potentially lead to a disseminated fungal infection if not treated promptly.
2. C. difficile infection: The patient was readmitted with C. difficile colitis, which can cause severe diarrhea and may require specific treatment.
3. Sepsis: The patient is still septic despite antibiotic therapy, indicating that the infection is not fully controlled.
4. Hypoxia: The patient is experiencing hypoxia, which may be due to fluid overload or altered mental status.
5. Altered mental status: The patient is lethargic and has low energy, indicating a possible alteration in mental status.
6. Hypotension: The patient requires low-dose pressors to maintain blood pressure, suggesting ongoing hypotension.
7. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level, indicating anemia.
8. DM: The patient's diabetes management requires adjustment due to her current critical condition.
9.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, and diabetes mellitus. She was admitted to the ICU for abdominal abscess debridement and treatment of gram-negative bacteremia and candidemia. The patient has been readmitted with Clostridium difficile colitis and new candidemia caused by Candida albicans. She is currently on invasive ventilation, successfully extubated around noon on [**4-17**]. The patient's condition is complicated by leukocytosis, fever, hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, ESRD on HD, hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, abdominal wound, portal venous and right internal jugular vein clots, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and other medical conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient's leukocytosis and fever suggest a possible disseminated fungal infection, which is consistent with her candidemia.
2. Candida sepsis: The patient's candidemia may progress to candida sepsis, a potentially life-threatening condition that requires prompt treatment.
3. Hypoxia: The patient's tachypnea on pressure support ventilation (PSV) indicates ongoing respiratory issues, possibly related to fluid overload or altered mental status. Close monitoring and further evaluation are necessary to determine the cause and appropriate management

Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old female with fungemia sepsis, who has undergone multiple interventions and procedures. The patient's current condition includes:

1. Candidemia/Sepsis: The patient has positive blood cultures indicating Candida albicans infection, likely acquired while on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and off micafungin. The patient is currently on micafungin and cdiff coverage with PO vancomycin and flagyl. Other site cultures have been negative, and there is a possibility of endocarditis, with plans for transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) this week.

2. Leukocytosis and fever: The patient's white blood cell count is trending upwards without fever, indicating a potential disseminated fungal infection. Other sites to evaluate include the abdominal wound and heart valves.

3. Hypoxia: The patient was intubated for airway protection but is now extubated. The patient's oxygenation has improved, but they remain tachypneic on pressure support ventilation (PSV), suggesting fluid-related or altered mental status. A trial spontaneous breathing test (SBT) will be conducted today to assess readiness for extubation.

4. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has improved since extubation but remains lethargic. No evidence of seizures post-extubation has been observed. Narcotic medications may have contributed to lethargy and should be used cautiously.

5.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 48-year-old female with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement, gram-negative bacteremia, and candidemia.
- She was transferred back to the MICU with lethargy and worsening leukocytosis in the setting of recently diagnosed C. difficile colitis.
- The patient has been intubated for airway protection due to hypoxia and is still dependent on pressors.
- She had candidemia likely related to a central line infection, which was treated with fluconazole for 23 days.
- Other medical conditions include altered mental status, leukocytosis, fever, hypoxia, altered mental status, hypotension, abdominal wound, portal venous and right internal jugular vein clots, HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy, ESRD on HD, and diabetes mellitus.
- The patient's current medications include micafungin, ambisome, cefepime, amikacin, vancomycin, PO vancomycin, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and insulin.
- The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count (22.2-27.2 K/uL), increased creatinine levels (2.8-3.6 mg/dL), and decreased hemoglobin levels (6.8 g/dL).
- The patient has been on hemodialysis and is currently awaiting a temporary HD line placement.
- The patient's recent imaging studies include a CT torso showing no evidence of empyema and a head CT with no evidence of bleed.
- The patient's family has been informed of the current situation, and code status remains full code.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Disseminated fungal infection: The patient has leukocytosis and fever, which are consistent with a disseminated fungal infection.
2. C. difficile infection: The patient has recently been diagnosed with C. difficile colitis.
3. Sepsis: The patient is still septic and requires pressors intermittently.
4. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is mainly due to airway protection, and there is a concern for fluid overload or altered mental status contributing to respiratory failure.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's acute onset of altered mental status with rapid improvement raises concern for a seizure or sedating medication effect.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is suspected to be due to sepsis, and she is on low-dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely.
7. Abdominal wound: The patient's abdominal wound is being managed with a wound vacuum but requires further evaluation and management by plastic surgery.
8. Portal venous and RIJ clots: The patient is on heparin gtt for the treatment of portal

4. Altered mental status: The patient

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, who has a history of abdominal wound infection, Clostridium difficile (CDif), and now candidemia. She has been in the ICU for an extended period and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to airway protection. The patient has been extubated successfully but still requires mild assistance with levophed. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature of 36.3Â°C (97.4Â°F), heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 109/48 mmHg to 151/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's rhythm is sinus rhythm, and she has facial edema, scleral icterus, and a systolic murmur on cardiovascular examination. Peripheral pulses are diminished in both upper and lower extremities. Respiratory examination reveals clear breath sounds. 

Abdominal examination shows tenderness but no rebound or guarding. There is evidence of right and left lower extremity edema. Musculoskeletal examination reveals muscle wasting, and the patient's skin is warm. Neurologic examination shows that the patient is attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, has purposeful movements, and decreased muscle tone.

Laboratory results indicate anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.8 g/dL

   Assessment and Plan
   48 yo F with ESRD on HD, HBV, recent prolonged hospitalization for PEG
   c/b abdominal abscess requiring debridement along with gram negative
   bacteremia and candidemia readmitted with C.difficile colitis and found
   to have new candidemia with [**Female First Name (un) **] albicans.
   .
   # Unresponsive episode
   Patient had similar episode on floor prompting her transfer to the ICU.
   Cause remains uncertain - consider seizure given prior CVA, metabolic
   abnormalities, infection. Limited EEG with only evidence of
   encephalopathy. Episode yesterday associated with hypotension and
   bradycardia
 one concern was aspiration event with vagal response.
   Consider also primary cardiac conduction disorder. Prior head CTs
   without evidence of cerebral abscess
   - Neurology recommendations appreciated
   - Consider MRI/MRA head with MRV to further assess for cerebral venous
   thrombosis
   - Will hold on LP for now with coagulopathy
   - 24hr EEG
   - limit medications likely to lower seizure threshold (eg quinolones,
   carbepenems) to extent possible
   # Anemia
   Patient
s hematocrit dropped 24->19 yesterday in setting of
   supratherapeutic PTT on heparin drip. No gross bleeding, and no clearly
   identified intrabdominal source of blood on CT overnight, though
   increased density of abdominal fluid raised question of a slow bleed
   however examination of fluid with diagnostic tap did not indicate
   significant bleeding. Labs overnight did not show any evidence of
   hemolysis. Could have slow GIB eg [**2-2**] gastritis
   - guiac stools, monitor closely for any evidence of bleeding
   - hodling heparin for now
   - check q6h hcts
   - transfuse hct>25
   - continue PPI
   - follow up final CT abdomen read
   # Candidemia
   She has not had any positive cultures since transfer to the ICU.
   Suspect related to lines (PICC and or old HD catheter) in setting of
   TPN. These have now been removed. Opthal eval without evidence of eye
   involvement.
   - Continue micafungin pending fluc sensitivities, pending today
   - F/u cultures and CIS
   - Await TEE
   - Favor reexamining thigh fluid collection as might have been seeded
   since last tap and would represent reservoir for recurrence
   # C diff colitis
   Toxin assays negative here.
   - Would continue PO vanc (day#1=[**4-1**]) and flagyl (day #1=[**4-5**]) for 10d
   post end of broad spectrum antibiotics. Will discuss whether flagyl
   required with ID team.
   # Hypotension:  Suspect [**2-2**] septic etiology. She appears
   intravascularly volume overloaded. Cortisol level normal. On very low
   dose Levophed but unable to wean off completely
   - Wean pressors as tolerated, on Levophed
   - monitor closely in setting of upcoming dialysis / CVVH today
   - Treating infection as above
   # ESRD on HD:
   Now on CVVH with new lines.
   - Renal recs appreciated
   - Fluid removal as BP tolerates, would try for -1L if possible as total
   body volume overloaded
   # HepB, autoimmune cholangiopathy:  S/p recent prednisone taper.
   Nutrition will be issue for the patient. Had abdominal infection s/p
   PEG placement, now with candidemia likely in setting of TPN.
   - Nutrition:  Dophoff placement for now vs re-evaluate ability to take
   POs (as will likely will not be enough intake & very  poor gag reflex
   now)
   - no steroids for now given sepsis and candidemia
   - Continue entecavir and tenofovir
   - Continue ursodiol
   - Continue to follow synthetic function tests daily
   - Liver recs appreciated
   # Abdominal wound: Wound vac changed Friday. ABD CT unchanged.
   - plastic surgery following, recs appreciated
   - continue local care, wound vac in place
   .
   # Portal venous and RIJ clots
   - Holding heparin for now given concern for bleeding
   .
   # DM:
   - Continue insulin
   - will d/c glargine for now and start on Humalog SSI until better
   intake w/Dobhoff feeds
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  holding tube feeds for TEE

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 48-year-old female with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD), hepatitis B, autoimmune cholangiopathy, recent prolonged hospitalization for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement with subsequent abdominal abscess requiring debridement, gram-negative bacteremia, and candidemia. She has been readmitted with Clostridium difficile colitis and a new episode of candidemia caused by Candida albicans. The patient experienced an episode of unresponsiveness with bradycardia and hypotension, which remains uncertain in cause, possibly due to a seizure, metabolic abnormalities, infection, or primary cardiac conduction disorder.

The patient's hematocrit dropped from 24 to 19 overnight, raising concerns of a slow gastrointestinal bleed, although examination of abdominal fluid did not indicate significant bleeding. The patient has been on heparin, but it has been held due to the potential risk of bleeding. She also has candidemia, likely related to lines (PICC and old HD catheter) in the setting of total parenteral nutrition (TPN). These lines have been removed, and micafungin has been continued pending fluconazole sensitivities.

The patient has been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile colitis, and toxin assays have been negative. She is being treated with vancomycin and flagyl for 14 days post-end of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Hypot
